text.p: These are the leading stories in the Turkish press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The military-dominated National Security Council does not discuss proposed crackdown on Islamist activism at a meeting on Monday. The issue has been left until another meeting at the end of this month.
- Coalition partner Tansu Ciller says the coalition cannot be broken by tanks or guns, in a reference to military pressure on the government.
- Head of the powerful Turkish Union Trade Bourses calls for the Islamist-led government to go.
- Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan thinks army will take step back in row over Islamic activism.

- Coalition partner are close to reaching an agreement over giving eight years of secularist education to children instead of the current five. Non-obligatory Arabic and Koranic lessons will be introduced in a compromise with Erbakan.
- The Islamist-run culture ministry forbids photograph exhibition because it is obscene.
- Turkey's Koc Holding is to invest in three new sectors, telecommunication, defence and energy.
- Uranium is found at a mountain in western Turkey.
